page.title: 03Great Hayes Farm
page.content: { Great Hayes Farm}is run by the cowman Dennis Parkes. He looks after 181 Friesian cows and one Hereford bull. All the cows have names and Mr. Parkes remembers most of them. He also knows the nature of his cows and the order they prefer for milking. The farm covers 360 acres, of which 200 acres is given over to grass. The grass is cut in early summer to make silage. This green grass ferments under some black plastic held down by many hundreds of tyres. In summer the grass is cut for hay. The busiest time of the year is between September to January, when the cows are calving. The cowman works a 13 hour day. He brings the cows from the field at 5 a.m. and milks them at 5.30a.m. They are milked again in the evening and returned to the field at 6.30p.m.
